title: 105_s745
content: The Act is titled the "Small Business Capital Gains Enhancement Act of 1997" and includes modifications to the exclusion of gain on certain small business stock. The Small Business Capital Gains Enhancement Act of 1997 increases the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 75%. This amendment also updates the headings and references in the Internal Revenue Code accordingly. The Small Business Capital Gains Enhancement Act of 1997 raises the exclusion for gain from small business stock to 75%. Amendments include excluding stock held by members of a controlled group and repealing the minimum tax preference. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from small business stock to $100,000,000 and make technical amendments to certain sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from small business stock to $100,000,000 and make technical amendments to certain sections, including raising the per-issuer limitation on taxpayer's gain to $20,000,000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the working capital period from 2 years to 5 years. Additionally, rules regarding stock redemption are modified to allow for a waiver if the corporation can prove a legitimate business purpose for the stock purchase. Effective dates for these changes are specified. Effective Dates: The amendments made by this section apply to stock issued after the date of the enactment of this Act, except for stock issued after August 10, 1993, which falls under special rules. SEC. 1045 allows for the rollover of gains on small business investments under certain conditions. The section allows for nonrecognition of gain on the sale of eligible small business investments if the taxpayer elects. Gain is only recognized if the amount realized exceeds the cost of other eligible investments purchased within 6 months, with certain definitions and rules applying. The term 'eligible small business investment' refers to stock or partnership interest in a domestic entity issued after December 31, 1996, meeting specific criteria. This includes being a qualified small business entity at the time of issuance and acquired by the taxpayer directly or through an underwriter in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services. The taxpayer must hold stock or partnership interest for at least 6 months before selling it. The entity must meet active business requirements for the investment to be considered eligible. The term 'qualified small business entity' refers to a domestic corporation or partnership with aggregate gross assets of less than $25,000,000 before and after the issuance of interest. The active business requirement for a qualified small business entity under subsection (b)(3) mandates that the entity must be actively engaged in a trade or business, with at least 80% of its assets used in the active conduct of a qualified trade or business. This requirement is not met if the entity falls under certain categories outlined in section 1202(e)(4). For certain activities related to startup, research, or in-house research expenses, an entity will be considered engaged in the active conduct of a trade or business. This determination is made without regard to specific sections outlined in the law. Rules similar to those in section 1202(e) apply for determining eligibility without considering current gross income. Other rules from section 1202 also apply, with a 6-month holding period instead of 5 years. Any unrecognized gain from a sale will reduce the basis of eligible small business investments acquired within 6 months. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies on gains from eligible small business investments is extended to 3 years if the taxpayer notifies the Secretary about their purchase of other investments resulting in nonrecognition of gain. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies on gains from eligible small business investments is extended to 3 years if the taxpayer notifies the Secretary about their purchase of other investments resulting in nonrecognition of gain. The Secretary shall prescribe regulations to prevent avoidance of the purposes of this section through various means. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions for small business investments. The table of sections is also updated to reflect these changes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions for small business investments, specifically regarding the rollover of gain. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 1996.
